questions.text: A 73-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening bilateral lower extremity pain for the past 8 months. The pain begins after walking one to two blocks and radiates bilaterally down the buttocks with cramping and tingling. He reports that the pain is worse while walking downhill and is relieved by sitting and leaning forward. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55 years and an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair at the age of 60 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. His current medications include sitagliptin, metformin, atorvastatin, metoprolol succinate, amlodipine, and hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 150/87 mm Hg. Examination shows full muscle strength. Sensation is reduced bilaterally in the feet and toes. Straight leg raise test is negative. X-ray of the spine shows degenerative changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Measurement of the ankle brachial index

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measurement of HLA-B27 antigen is performed in patients with suspected ankylosing spondylitis. The most characteristic findings include dull pain in the neck and lower back independent of positioning, limited mobility of the spine, and morning stiffness that improves with activity. In addition, onset is usually prior to age 40 and the disease follows a gradual, progressive course. Although the x-ray findings described in this case could indicate ankylosing spondylitis, the typical clinical features are absent in the patient, making it an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

X-ray of the lumbar spine (lateral view, standing position) in a patient with suspected ankylosing spondylitis

Sclerosis of the facet joints, particularly L3–S1 (examples indicated by green lines), can be seen. Additionally, there are signs of degenerative changes (e.g., the formation of vertebral body bone spurs) and spinal structure defect. The typical "bamboo spine" appearance is not present here. (S = sacrum)

B) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the ankle brachial index is an easy way to screen for peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Although the patient has multiple cardiovascular risk factors that increase the risk for PAD, this diagnosis is unlikely because PAD would manifest with claudication that occurs after walking a certain distance and does not resolve with spinal flexion. Other typical features of PAD include erectile dysfunction, diminished lower extremity pulses, and trophic changes, none of which are present in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

MRI scan of the spine is the imaging modality of choice to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of stenosis and compression of neural structures in a patient presenting with neurogenic claudication. Spondylolisthesis, degenerative disk disease, and facet joint arthropathy are the most common causes of spinal stenosis and can usually be identified with MRI imaging.
Image Description:

MRI lumbar spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

Advanced degenerative changes (red overlay) involve the intervertebral disks and posterior elements at multiple levels. The spinal canal (green overlay) is narrowed at L2–3 and L3–4 (indicated by arrows).

White dashed outline: spinal cord

D) INCORRECT:

Polysomnography is the diagnostic test of choice for restless legs syndrome (RLS). The test quantifies so-called periodic limb movements of sleep (PLMS), which is a common finding in RLS but is not present in this patient. Although dysesthesias (e.g., pain, pins and needles, tickling sensations) may be present in RLS, it is primarily characterized by an urge to move the legs, which is relieved by movement and worsened by rest, making this diagnosis very unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum creatine kinase is an appropriate next step if myositis is suspected. The key clinical finding is symmetric proximal muscle weakness, which can manifest as pain while walking, but other findings such as difficulty combing hair, standing up, and climbing stairs would be present as well. Furthermore, patients with myositis commonly have muscle tenderness and cutaneous manifestations (such as Gottron papules), which this patient lacks.
questions.hint: Bilateral buttock pain that worsens with lumbar extension (e.g., walking) and is relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting, leaning forward) is consistent with neurogenic claudication, which is commonly seen in lumbar spinal stenosis. Symptoms of neurogenic claudication can occur in the absence of lower back pain.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of lower back pain and tingling and numbness in his legs for the past 6 months. The pain radiates bilaterally to his buttocks and legs and gets worse while standing or walking downhill. Two weeks ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His son has ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. The patient does not smoke. He drinks two to three beers on the weekends. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. There is no tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. The patient's gait is unsteady and wide-based. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Seronegative spondyloarthropathies have a strong genetic association with HLA-B27 and frequently manifest with lower back pain. This patient is at increased risk for seronegative spondyloarthropathies given his family history, but those diseases are usually present before age 40. Additionally, they typically manifest with reduced range of motion and enthesitis and they do not cause neurologic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

An increased HbA1c occurs in diabetes mellitus (DM) and is not commonly associated with spinal stenosis. This patient has several risk factors for type 2 diabetes mellitus (weight, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia), and long-standing DM may lead to diabetic neuropathy that manifests with sensory deficits and reduced reflexes as seen in this patient. However, diabetic neuropathy does not account for this patient's radiating back pain.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive straight leg raise test suggests back pain secondary to degenerative disk disease and is not a common finding in spinal stenosis. This patient's lower radiating back pain, sensory deficits, and reduced reflexes may be consistent with degenerative disk disease. However, degenerative disk disease primarily causes dermatomal sensory deficits, decreased leg strength, and reduced deep tendon reflexes only of the muscles innervated by the compressed nerve root.

An anterior disk herniation into the cauda equina could cause bilateral and multi-dermatomal/myotomal symptoms, but the association of symptoms with exertion and chronic duration makes herniation unlikely (most herniations self-resolve/improve within 6–8 weeks) and this patient has no history of trauma (e.g., heavy lifting) to explain a herniation.

D) INCORRECT:

Albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF analysis is seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which sometimes follows an upper respiratory infection like the one this patient had. GBS may account for this patient's back and limb pain and his reduced muscle reflexes. However, GBS typically also causes a rapidly progressive ascending flaccid paralysis that self-resolves within weeks to months, whereas this patient has had chronic symptoms with intact muscle strength.

E) CORRECT:

Postural changes can widen or narrow the spinal canal and thereby alleviate or worsen symptoms of spinal stenosis. By leaning forward, the spinal canal is widened and spinal cord compression is reduced. Therefore, leaning forward will most likely relieve this patient's back pain. Activities that flex the lumbar spine, such as sitting, cycling, or walking uphill, also help widen the spinal canal and alleviate pain in patients with spinal stenosis.

The exacerbation of lumbar spinal stenosis symptoms by certain postures that narrow the spinal cord (walking downhill, standing, walking) is called pseudoclaudication. In contrast to vascular claudication, which is a result of arterial vessel narrowing and impaired metabolic demands of muscle tissue, pseudoclaudication is thought to result from increased metabolic demands of a compressed and ischemic spinal cord.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

F) INCORRECT:

A decreased ankle-brachial index is seen in peripheral arterial disease (PAD), which also manifests with lower extremity pain with exertion (i.e., claudication). This patient has several risk factors for developing PAD (hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, advanced age), but his pain has a radiculopathic character and is also exacerbated by standing upright, neither of which are seen in PAD.
questions.hint: Lower extremity radiculopathy that worsens with standing or walking downhill is consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old woman with coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes reports a 6-month history of worsening low back pain that radiates to her buttocks and thighs. The pain is exacerbated by standing or walking, and it improves with rest. She occasionally experiences paresthesias in her feet. She denies weakness in her lower extremities.
Her vital signs are normal, and all of her pulses are palpable. She has no focal neurologic deficits on physical examination.
Which one of the following questions would be most useful to ask this patient in order to confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Does leaning forward relieve the pain?
Does leaning backward relieve the pain?
Do you have foot and calf pain at rest?
Do you have intermittent pain that feels like an electric shock and radiates down one leg to the foot?
Is the back pain worse in the morning?

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spinal column that can put pressure on the spinal cord and nerve roots, resulting in pain, numbness, or weakness. The most common cause is degenerative disease, typically occurring at the level of L3–4 and L4–5, and onset is therefore typically at an older age.

Patients with spinal stenosis usually experience pain in their back, legs, or both, but tingling, numbness, and weakness can also happen with or without pain. The pain associated with lumbar spinal stenosis frequently radiates into the buttock, thigh, and lower leg. Symptoms are usually bilateral and often worse when extending the back such as when walking (especially downhill) or standing. The symptoms tend to resolve when the patient sits or flexes forward while walking (such as when walking uphill).

Vascular claudication is precipitated by movement and is not typically influenced by posture alone (i.e., standing without walking).

Key learning point: The most typical clinical manifestation of lumbar spinal stenosis is neurogenic claudication.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with spinal stenosis usually experience pain in their back, legs, or both, but tingling, numbness, and weakness can also happen with or without pain. The pain associated with lumbar spinal stenosis frequently radiates into the buttock, thigh, and lower leg. Symptoms are usually bilateral and often worse when extending the back such as when walking (especially downhill) or standing.

C) INCORRECT:

Foot and calf pain at rest are not typical features of lumbar spinal stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Intermittent pain that feels like an electric shock radiating to one calf and foot is more typical of radiculopathy (sciatica) caused by a bulging intervertebral disk rather than the combination of chronic degenerative changes that characterize lumbar spinal stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory back pain from a spondyloarthropathy is often worse in the morning and typically has onset of symptoms before age 40.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes reports that she has had progressive difficulty walking during the past year and has fallen twice. Her legs often feel heavy after she has been walking, causing her to limit her activities. When she sits down, her symptoms resolve completely within a few minutes. She noticed the symptoms most recently while at the grocery store but reports that she can typically finish shopping if she walks bent over the cart. She notes that walking uphill is easier than walking downhill.
The patient has no bowel or bladder symptoms. She has had diabetes-related numbness in her feet for several years, but she reports that her blood sugar has been under relatively good control and that her current symptoms are different from those associated with her previous neuropathy.
On examination, her mental status and cranial nerves are intact. She has normal strength in all four extremities, with normal bulk, tone, and reflexes. She has no sensory level but exhibits diminished sensation to light touch and pinprick in a stocking-glove distribution, with decreased vibration sense and proprioception at both great toes.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Nerve-conduction study of the lower extremities
Plain radiograph of the lumbar spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ankle-brachial index would be an excellent initial test to help diagnose peripheral vascular disease. Although this patient is at high risk for vascular claudication, her symptoms are more suggestive of neurogenic claudication. Neurogenic claudication tends to involve the entire leg, whereas vascular claudication is more likely to be isolated to one or both calves. Weakness and thigh pain are both possible in vascular claudication, but unlike in this patient, the symptoms of vascular claudication tend to be better with standing upright and worse with walking uphill or upstairs. Furthermore, although a low ankle-brachial index might suggest vascular claudication, further testing would be indicated to confirm the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A muscle biopsy would be the test of choice if a myopathy or myositis were highest on the list of differential diagnoses. Myositis results in substantial proximal-muscle weakness and tenderness to palpation, which this patient does not report, and is not improved by positional changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has evidence of a neuropathy on examination (sensory changes in a stocking-glove distribution), likely related to her long-standing diabetes, the symptoms she currently reports are more likely related to spinal stenosis than to a progressive neuropathy. A nerve-conduction study may show the neuropathy as well as a radiculopathy related to spinal stenosis, but the study is not necessary for diagnosis and is not as helpful as an MRI, given the suspicion of stenosis.

D) CORRECT:

Spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spinal column that can put pressure on the spinal cord and nerve roots, resulting in pain, numbness, or weakness. The most common cause is degenerative disease, typically occurring at the level of L3–4 and L4–5.

Patients with spinal stenosis usually experience pain in their back, legs, or both, but tingling and weakness can also happen with or without pain. Symptoms are usually bilateral and tend to resolve when the patient sits or flexes forward while walking.

Both MRI and CT of the lumbar spine can confirm spinal stenosis. Bony lesions are often better visualized on CT, whereas soft-tissue abnormalities and intrinsic spinal-cord findings are better visualized on MRI. MRI is often considered the diagnostic study of choice for spinal stenosis.

Key learning point: The best test to evaluate for spinal stenosis is MRI of the lumbar spine.

E) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs of the lumbar spine might show degenerative changes, but these changes are nonspecific and insufficient to make a diagnosis of spinal stenosis. Neuroimaging with CT or MRI is indicated to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out other causes of weakness or pain.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes reports worsening back discomfort and bilateral leg pain when he walks his dog each day. He denies any recent trauma, sensory symptoms, or bowel or bladder incontinence but has noticed that the leg pain has worsened during the past few weeks. The pain now occurs after he walks only a few blocks, but it improves if he sits to rest or if he bends forward at the waist to walk uphill.
On physical examination, his pedal pulses cannot be appreciated, but his extremities are warm and well perfused. He is currently asymptomatic with intact strength, sensation, and reflexes in all four limbs. Vibration and proprioception are intact at the great toe. When he walks down the office hallway, he reports no pain and has a normal, narrow-based gait.
Which one of the following conditions is most likely to explain this patient’s pain?

choices.text: Radiculopathy related to a growing tumor
Impaired muscular blood supply related to peripheral vascular disease
Neurogenic claudication related to spinal stenosis
Myelopathy related to a bulging disk

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of peripheral neuropathy would not change when the patient sits down to rest or adjusts his posture.

B) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of nerve-root compression (radiculopathy) would not change when the patient sits down to rest or adjusts his posture.

C) INCORRECT:

Spinal stenosis typically causes leg pain during walking and is relieved by rest, making it easy to confuse with leg pain that stems from other causes such as vascular insufficiency. However, patients with spinal stenosis typically describe pain that radiates down their legs or progressive weakness that is relieved with bending forward while walking, as this patient reports. Symptoms of vascular claudication stem from impaired muscular blood supply and are not typically relieved with changes in posture. Spinal stenosis often continues to cause pain when the patient is standing erect and still, whereas vascular claudication usually causes pain only when the patient is moving.

D) CORRECT:

Spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spinal column that can put pressure on the spinal cord and nerve roots, resulting in pain, numbness, and weakness. The most common cause is degenerative disease, typically occurring at the level of L3–4 and L4–5.

Spinal stenosis typically causes leg pain during walking and is relieved by rest, making it easy to confuse with leg pain that stems from other causes such as vascular insufficiency. However, patients with spinal stenosis typically describe pain that radiates down their legs or progressive weakness that is relieved with bending forward while walking, as this patient reports. Symptoms of vascular claudication stem from impaired muscular blood supply and are not typically relieved with changes in posture. Spinal stenosis often continues to cause pain when the patient is standing erect and still, whereas vascular claudication usually causes pain only when the patient is moving.

Aside from classic presenting symptoms, neurogenic claudication can be distinguished from vascular claudication with normal vascular studies and evidence of stenosis on spinal imaging (CT or MRI). Treatment for neurogenic claudication is typically conservative, including nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and postural changes, although surgery may be considered in severe cases.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of worsening bilateral leg pain that occurs while the patient is walking and improves with sitting down or bending forward at the waist is neurogenic claudication related to spinal stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of spinal cord injury (myelopathy) would not change when the patient sits down to rest or adjusts his posture.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with lower back pain and tingling and numbness in his legs for the past 6 months. The pain radiates bilaterally to his buttocks and legs and gets worse while standing or walking downhill. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. There is no tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. The patient's gait is unsteady and wide-based. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?

However, seronegative spondyloarthropathies are usually present before age 40. Additionally, they typically manifest with reduced range of motion and enthesitis and they do not cause neurologic symptoms.

However, diabetic neuropathy does not account for this patient's radiating back pain.

However, degenerative disk disease primarily causes dermatomal sensory deficits, decreased leg strength, and reduced deep tendon reflexes only of the muscles innervated by the compressed nerve root.

An anterior disk herniation into the cauda equina could cause bilateral and multi-dermatomal/myotomal symptoms, but the association of symptoms with exertion and chronic duration makes herniation unlikely (most herniations self-resolve/improve within 6–8 weeks) and this patient has no history of trauma (e.g., heavy lifting) to explain a herniation.

D) INCORRECT:

Albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF analysis is seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). GBS may account for this patient's back and limb pain and his reduced muscle reflexes. However, GBS typically also causes a rapidly progressive ascending flaccid paralysis that self-resolves within weeks to months, whereas this patient has had chronic symptoms with intact muscle strength.

The exacerbation of lumbar spinal stenosis symptoms by certain postures that narrow the spinal cord (walking downhill, standing, walking) is called pseudoclaudication. In contrast to vascular claudication, which is a result of arterial vessel narrowing and impaired metabolic demands of muscle tissue, pseudoclaudication is thought to result from increased metabolic demands of a compressed and ischemic spinal cord.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.
questions.hint: Lower extremity radiculopathy that worsens with standing or walking downhill is consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis.

X-ray of the lumbar spine (lateral view, standing position) in a patient with suspected ankylosing spondylitis

MRI lumbar spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

Advanced degenerative changes (red overlay) involve the intervertebral disks and posterior elements at multiple levels. The spinal canal (green overlay) is narrowed at L2–3 and L3–4 (indicated by arrows).

White dashed outline: spinal cord

D) INCORRECT:

Polysomnography is the diagnostic test of choice for restless legs syndrome (RLS). The test quantifies so-called periodic limb movements of sleep (PLMS), which is a common finding in RLS but is not present in this patient. Symptoms of neurogenic claudication can occur in the absence of lower back pain.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents with 6 months of progressively worsening bilateral calf and thigh pain after walking one block. The pain resolves within a minute when he flexes at his waist and leans on a counter or walks on an incline, allowing him to continue walking further. He denies similar discomfort while standing upright. Physical examination shows normal peripheral pulses and a normal ankle-brachial index.
Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trochanteric bursitis presents as localized lateral hip pain with tenderness over the greater trochanter. The patient's bilateral calf and thigh pain, relieved by leaning forward, suggests a neurogenic cause. The absence of hip tenderness and normal vascular findings further argue against trochanteric bursitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) causes exertional leg pain that typically improves with rest, not specific postural changes. PAD often presents with diminished peripheral pulses and an abnormal ankle-brachial index, which are absent here. The patient's pain relief with lumbar flexion suggests a neurogenic rather than vascular origin.

C) CORRECT:

Lumbar spinal stenosis is characterized by narrowing of the spinal canal, often due to degenerative changes like facet joint hypertrophy and ligamentum flavum thickening. It commonly affects older individuals and manifests with neurogenic claudication, presenting as lower extremity pain during ambulation that is relieved by lumbar flexion. This position increases the spinal canal diameter, reducing nerve root compression. The patient's symptom relief with forward bending and normal peripheral pulses and ankle-brachial index suggest a neurological rather than vascular cause, supporting this diagnosis.

Key learning point: Neurogenic claudication, characterized by leg pain relieved by bending forward or walking uphill, is indicative of lumbar spinal stenosis.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

D) INCORRECT:

L5-S1 disc herniation usually causes unilateral radicular pain with focal neurologic deficits, such as sensory loss or motor weakness. The patient's bilateral calf and thigh pain, relieved by lumbar flexion, indicates a posture-dependent phenomenon rather than radiculopathy, making disc herniation unlikely.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents with three months of chronic lower back pain that worsens with prolonged standing and walking. He finds some relief when bending forward or sitting. There is no radiation of pain, bowel or bladder incontinence, or lower extremity weakness or numbness. Examination shows a normal gait and a negative straight leg raise test. He has no focal neurological deficits (see report).
Lumbar spine radiographs: Mild degenerative changes with narrowed disc spaces and mild central canal narrowing at L4-L5
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Urgent MRI of the lumbar spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urgent MRI is indicated when there are red flag symptoms, such as neurological deficits or signs of cauda equina syndrome. This patient has chronic lower back pain without alarming symptoms, and mild degenerative changes on radiographs are consistent with age-related changes. MRI is reserved for cases unresponsive to conservative management or with potential serious pathology.

B) INCORRECT:

Long-term opioids are not first-line therapy for uncomplicated chronic lower back pain due to risks of dependency and adverse effects. This patient's mechanical pain pattern is best managed with nonpharmacologic interventions and short-term use of less potent analgesics, emphasizing conservative management.

C) CORRECT:

A supervised physical therapy program is the preferred initial management for mild lumbar spinal stenosis. This approach enhances core stability, improves posture, and strengthens the lower back. The patient's symptoms, which worsen with standing and improve with flexion, align with mild central canal narrowing. Physical therapy uses targeted exercises to decompress the lumbar spine by optimizing biomechanics and reducing stress on affected segments. This noninvasive management decreases pain, improves function, and slows degenerative progression, making it suitable in the absence of neurological deficits.

Key learning point: For mild lumbar spinal stenosis with mechanical back pain and no neurological deficits, physical therapy is an appropriate first-line management strategy to improve flexibility, strengthen muscles, and reduce pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical decompression is reserved for severe cases with progressive neurological deficits, such as motor weakness or incontinence. This patient has chronic lower back pain with no neurological deficits and mild degenerative changes on imaging, which do not warrant surgical intervention. Conservative management is appropriate given the absence of significant neurogenic claudication or neurological impairment.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of lower back pain accompanied by tingling and numbness in his legs. The pain radiates bilaterally to his buttocks and legs and worsens with standing or walking downhill. His medical history includes hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He is 180 cm tall and weighs 90 kg; BMI is 28. There is no tenderness over the lumbar spine. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased in the lower extremities. His gait is unsteady and wide-based. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally, and Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Which one of the following findings is most likely to be revealed on further evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Postural changes can widen or narrow the spinal canal and thereby alleviate or worsen symptoms of spinal stenosis. By leaning forward, the spinal canal is widened and spinal cord compression is reduced. Therefore, leaning forward will most likely relieve this patient's back pain. Activities that flex the lumbar spine, such as sitting, cycling, or walking uphill, also help widen the spinal canal and alleviate pain in patients with spinal stenosis.

The exacerbation of lumbar spinal stenosis symptoms by certain postures that narrow the spinal cord (walking downhill, standing, walking) is called pseudoclaudication. In contrast to vascular claudication, which is a result of arterial vessel narrowing and impaired metabolic demands of muscle tissue, pseudoclaudication is thought to result from increased metabolic demands of a compressed and ischemic spinal cord.

Key learning point: Lumbar spinal stenosis symptoms are typically relieved by lumbar flexion, such as leaning forward, which widens the spinal canal and reduces nerve compression.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

B) INCORRECT:

Albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF analysis is seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). GBS may account for this patient's back and limb pain and his reduced muscle reflexes. However, GBS typically also causes a rapidly progressive ascending flaccid paralysis that self-resolves within weeks to months, whereas this patient has had chronic symptoms with intact muscle strength.

C) INCORRECT:

Seronegative spondyloarthropathies have a strong genetic association with HLA-B27 and frequently manifest with lower back pain. However, seronegative spondyloarthropathies are usually present before age 40. Additionally, they typically manifest with reduced range of motion and enthesitis and they do not cause neurologic symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

A positive straight leg raise test suggests back pain secondary to degenerative disk disease and is not a common finding in spinal stenosis. This patient's lower radiating back pain, sensory deficits, and reduced reflexes may be consistent with degenerative disk disease. However, degenerative disk disease primarily causes dermatomal sensory deficits, decreased leg strength, and reduced deep tendon reflexes only of the muscles innervated by the compressed nerve root.

An anterior disk herniation into the cauda equina could cause bilateral and multi-dermatomal/myotomal symptoms, but the association of symptoms with exertion and chronic duration makes herniation unlikely (most herniations self-resolve/improve within 6–8 weeks) and this patient has no history of trauma (e.g., heavy lifting) to explain a herniation.

E) INCORRECT:

An increased HbA1c occurs in diabetes mellitus (DM) and is not commonly associated with spinal stenosis. This patient has several risk factors for type 2 diabetes mellitus (weight, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia), and long-standing DM may lead to diabetic neuropathy that manifests with sensory deficits and reduced reflexes as seen in this patient. However, diabetic neuropathy does not account for this patient's radiating back pain.
questions.hint: Lower extremity radiculopathy that worsens with standing or walking downhill is consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman returns to the ED for a flare-up of chronic pain. She has a 6-month history of right leg pain and low back discomfort that worsens with walking, especially downhill, and improves when sitting. There is no bowel or bladder dysfunction. Physical examination shows a wide-based gait, diminished lower extremity reflexes, and mild weakness in ankle dorsiflexion. Rectal tone and sensation are normal. A recent MRI of the lumbar spine showed moderate spinal canal narrowing at L3–L4 and L4–L5 with nerve root compression. She has tried NSAIDs and completed 8 weeks of physiotherapy with minimal improvement. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Prescribe activity restriction and bed rest
Discharge with a trial of gabapentin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activity restriction and bed rest are not recommended for the management of spinal stenosis. These measures do not address the underlying pathology and may lead to deconditioning and worsening of symptoms. Continued activity is preferred to maintain function and mobility.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has moderate lumbar spinal stenosis on imaging, with characteristic symptoms that are refractory to conservative therapy with NSAIDs and physiotherapy. This combination warrants a semi-urgent neurosurgery referral for consideration of decompressive surgery. If a timely referral cannot be arranged, bridging measures include optimizing analgesia (e.g., adding a neuropathic pain medication), referral to a multimodal pain specialist, and patient education (e.g., limit standing for long periods without support).

C) INCORRECT:

While gabapentin can be used for neuropathic pain conditions, including neurogenic claudication from spinal stenosis, this patient has moderate stenosis with failed conservative management. Additional medication for neuropathic pain could help provide this patient relief as a bridging measure, but should not delay definitive intervention for the underlying mechanical compression.

D) INCORRECT:

Epidural steroid injection is considered second-line therapy for persistent symptoms, but this patient has moderate stenosis with unsuccessful conservative management. The effects of epidural injections are short-lived, and although they could help provide this patient relief as a bridging measure, they should not delay definitive intervention for the underlying mechanical compression.

E) INCORRECT:

Urgent MRI with contrast would be indicated for patients with rapidly progressive neurological deficits or suspected compressive spinal emergencies such as cauda equina syndrome or conus medullaris syndrome. This patient has chronically progressive symptoms but lacks the acute neurological deterioration or other red flags for back pain that would warrant an urgent MRI.
